grounding.source: Simulation specification: US-only population
grounding.note: Fixed to United States per simulation scope

constraints.reason: Adults only; minimum age for the simulation
Upper age cap per simulation specification

grounding.source: US Census Bureau Vintage 2024; census.gov/data/tables/time-series/demo/popest/2020s-national-detail.html
grounding.note: Largest adult age group is 30-40 per Visual Capitalist / Census 2024 data; median adult age ~46 within 18-80 range; std reflects flattish adult distribution. Truncated normal applied within 18-80.

grounding.source: Wikipedia Demographics of the United States; 2020 Census: females 50.9%, males 49.1%; Gallup 2022 transgender/nonbinary ~1.6%
grounding.note: 2020 Census reported females at 50.9%, males at 49.1% of total population. Non-binary/Other estimated at ~1.5% of adults based on Gallup surveys, slightly reducing male/female shares.

grounding.source: neilsberg.com citing ACS 2019-2023; visualcapitalist.com 2023 racial breakdown; Census QuickFacts 2024
grounding.note: Non-Hispanic white ~57.5% (adults skew slightly more white than total population); Black ~12.4%; Hispanic/Latino ~18.5% (adults slightly lower than total pop); Asian ~6.2%; Other/Multiracial ~5.4%. We...[truncated]

grounding.source: Census Bureau regional population estimates; USAFacts population 2024
grounding.note: Census defines 4 regions; 5-region model used here (Southeast separated from South, Southwest carved out). Northeast ~17%, Southeast ~25% (South minus SW), Midwest ~21%, Southwest ~15%, West Coast ~22...[truncated]

grounding.source: HUD/Census 2017 American Housing Survey: 52% suburban, 27% urban, 21% rural (huduser.gov)
grounding.note: 2017 AHS self-identification data: 52% suburban, 27% urban, 21% rural. These self-reported shares are stable and widely cited. Used directly.

grounding.source: Big Five personality research; Schmitt et al. 2007 cross-cultural BFI; Rentfrow US state personality studies
grounding.note: US adults score moderately high on Openness. BFI scores normalized to 0-1 scale. Mean ~0.60 reflects US sample means slightly above midpoint. Std 0.18 reflects substantial individual variation documen...[truncated]

grounding.source: Rentfrow et al. US personality research; ScienceDirect personality of US states 2016
grounding.note: Conscientiousness is consistently the highest-scoring Big Five trait in US adult samples. Mean ~0.65 reflects above-midpoint normative scores. Std 0.17 reflects typical BFI individual variation.

grounding.source: Schmitt et al. 2007 BFI cross-national study; Rentfrow US personality geography studies
grounding.note: US adults score near midpoint on Extraversion with slightly above-average tendency. Mean 0.55, wider std 0.19 capturing introvert-to-extravert range.

grounding.source: Schmitt et al. 2007; Rentfrow et al. US state Big Five studies
grounding.note: Agreeableness moderately high in US normative samples. Mean 0.62 reflects positive but not extreme social cooperation tendency.

grounding.source: Schmitt et al. 2007; Big Five normative data for US adult samples
grounding.note: Neuroticism near midpoint in US adult samples; women score higher on average. Mean 0.45 slightly below midpoint with wide spread (std 0.19).

grounding.source: Census Bureau ACS 2023; Pew Research 2020 electorate education report; highereddatastories.com 2025
grounding.note: Pew notes 36% of registered voters have 4-year degree+; Census ACS 2022-2023 adult education: ~9% less than HS, ~27% HS/GED, ~27% some college, ~22% bachelor's, ~15% graduate. Consistent with multiple...[truncated]

constraints.reason: Minimum plausible household income for non-institutionalized adults
99th percentile upper bound; extreme wealth outliers excluded from representative sample

grounding.source: Census Bureau CPS ASEC 2024; US median household income ~$80,610 (2023); lognormal parameters: mean of log ~11.1 yields median ~$66k, mean ~$80k
grounding.note: US median household income was ~$74,580 in 2022, ~$80,610 in 2023 (Census). Lognormal is standard for income distributions. Log-mean 11.1 ≈ median $66k, log-std 0.75 produces realistic right skew with...[truncated]

grounding.source: Census Bureau CPS 2023; ACS 2022-2023 marital status for adults 18+
grounding.note: Census 2023: ~49-50% married/partnered, ~31% never married (single), ~13-14% divorced/separated, ~6% widowed among adults 18+. These are well-established stable figures.

constraints.reason: Households larger than 10 are extremely rare in the US

grounding.source: Census Bureau CPS 2023; average US household size 2.53 persons (2022-2023 ACS)
grounding.note: US average household size 2.53 in 2022 (Census). Distribution is right-skewed but approximated with truncated normal. Std 1.4 reflects wide range from 1-person to large family households.

grounding.source: Census Bureau CPS 2023; ~29-32% of US households have children under 18
grounding.note: Census data consistently shows ~29-32% of households include own children under 18. Probability_true set to 0.30 reflecting households with at least one child under 18 currently living at home.

grounding.source: BLS Current Population Survey 2024; Census Bureau ACS employment class 2023
grounding.note: Federal government ~2.9M workers (~2% of adult pop); state/local ~20M (~7%); private sector ~130M (~47%); gig/contract ~7%; self-employed ~10M (~7%); retired ~17%; unemployed ~4%; NILF ~9%. Weights su...[truncated]

grounding.source: Gallup Work and Education polls; SHRM worker confidence surveys 2023-2024
grounding.note: Gallup and Pew surveys consistently show ~55-60% of employed workers feel secure (very+somewhat). N/A ~23% aligns with retired+unemployed+NILF combined. Somewhat insecure ~11%, very insecure ~6% refle...[truncated]

grounding.source: PYMNTS/LendingClub paycheck-to-paycheck report 2023-2024; Federal Reserve Report on Economic Well-Being 2023
grounding.note: ~61-65% of Americans live paycheck-to-paycheck per LendingClub 2023; Fed Reserve shows ~37% couldn't cover $400 emergency. Breakout: comfortable ~22%, modest ~25%, P2P ~33%, debt/deficit ~20%.

grounding.source: Federal Reserve SCF 2022; Gallup stock ownership surveys 2023; Pew crypto ownership 2024
grounding.note: ~55% of Americans own stocks (Gallup 2023); Fed SCF: ~50% have retirement accounts; ~30% have no investments. Crypto: Pew 2022 finds ~16% have invested in crypto. Active traders ~8%. Categories are pa...[truncated]

grounding.source: Reuters Institute Digital News Report 2024; Pew Research media consumption surveys 2023-2024
grounding.note: Reuters/Pew 2023-2024: TV news ~24% primary source (declining), social media ~23% (rising esp. among younger), online news ~20%, local news ~10%, podcasts ~8% (growing), print ~5%, news avoiders ~10%.

grounding.source: Pew Research Social Media Use 2023; Reuters Institute Digital News Report 2024
grounding.note: Pew 2023: ~70-72% of US adults use social media. Of users, majority are passive (lurk/scroll). ~12% non-users (older, rural). Active poster/influencer estimated ~12% of adults. Passive consumer is the...[truncated]

grounding.source: Rogers Diffusion of Innovations model; Pew Research Technology Adoption 2023
grounding.note: Rogers canonical model: Innovators 2.5%, Early Adopters 13.5%, Early Majority 34%, Late Majority 34%, Laggards 16%. Adjusted for 2024 US adult population digital context: Innovators ~7%, Early Adopter...[truncated]

grounding.source: Pew Research Center Religious Landscape Study 2023-2024; Gallup church attendance 2024
grounding.note: Pew 2023-2024: ~28-30% religiously unaffiliated ('nones'); ~25% nominally affiliated (identify but rarely practice); ~27% moderately religious (attend occasionally); ~20% devout (attend weekly+, highl...[truncated]

grounding.source: Pew Research NPORS 2025; Pew 2024 partisan coalitions report
grounding.note: Pew NPORS 2025: 46% Republican/lean R, 45% Democrat/lean D, ~9% true independent. Strong partisan: ~16-17% each side; Leaners ~16-17% each; True Independent ~15%. Total ~81% partisan-leaning + 15% ind...[truncated]

grounding.source: ANES 2022-2024; Pew political engagement studies; voter turnout data
grounding.note: 2020 voter turnout ~66%, 2022 midterm ~47%. Disengaged ~20% (never vote, no interest); single-issue ~18%; moderate/occasional ~37%; highly engaged partisan ~25% (donate, campaign, always vote in all e...[truncated]

grounding.source: FEC 2024 certified results; ~77M Trump votes, ~75M Harris votes of ~340M US adults; ~15% non-citizens/ineligible
grounding.note: Trump won with ~49.9% of popular vote, Harris ~48.4% of popular vote. Turnout ~64% of eligible voters. ~15% of US adults are non-citizens (not eligible). Of eligible adults: ~60% voted (~30% Trump, ~2...[truncated]

grounding.source: MIT Election Lab midterm turnout data; Census Bureau CPS Voting Supplement 2022; ANES
grounding.note: 2022 midterm turnout ~47% of eligible voters (~113M votes). 'Always votes' in midterms ~32% (consistent high-propensity voters). 'Sometimes' ~27% (vote in some midterms). 'Rarely' ~21% (presidential o...[truncated]

grounding.source: Cook Political Report 2024 House ratings; Sabato Crystal Ball 2024 cycle
grounding.note: Cook Political 2024: ~180-190 safe R seats, ~155-165 safe D seats, ~35-50 competitive seats out of 435. Population-weighted (urban districts are denser): Safe R ~35%, Lean R ~12%, Swing ~12%, Lean D ~...[truncated]

grounding.source: Gallup most important problem Jan 2025; Pew 2024 election issue priorities; Harvard Youth Poll Fall 2025
grounding.note: Economy/Jobs consistently #1 (Gallup 2025: 25-30% most important). Immigration elevated post-2024 (~16%). Abortion ~13% (remains salient post-Dobbs). Democracy/ROL ~12%. Healthcare ~12%. Climate ~7%. ...[truncated]

grounding.source: Gallup right/wrong track polls 2025; Harvard Youth Poll Fall 2025; RealClearPolitics direction polls
grounding.note: Harvard Youth Poll Fall 2025: only 13% of young adults say country headed right direction. Gallup 2025: ~30-35% right track overall. 'Strongly approve' ~18%, 'Somewhat approve' ~22%, 'Somewhat disappr...[truncated]

grounding.source: McKinsey Consumer Sentiment 2023; Deloitte Consumer Signals 2024; Nielsen consumer loyalty research
grounding.note: McKinsey 2023: price/value is primary driver for ~36-40% of consumers (inflation era). Brand loyalty ~22%. Values/ethics-driven ~18% (growing among younger demographics). Convenience-driven ~22% (Amaz...[truncated]

grounding.source: Gallup institutional confidence survey 2024; Edelman Trust Barometer 2024; Harvard Youth Poll Fall 2025
grounding.note: Gallup 2024: confidence in major institutions at or near historic lows. Only ~12% have high confidence across government, media, corporations. Moderate trust ~31%. Low trust ~37%. Edelman 2024 finds ~...[truncated]

constraints.reason: Risk tolerance floored at 0 (maximally risk averse)
Risk tolerance capped at 1 (maximally risk tolerant)

grounding.source: Federal Reserve SCF financial risk tolerance 2022; Vanguard investor risk survey; academic risk preference literature
grounding.note: Beta(2.5, 3.0) produces mean ~0.455 with slight left skew toward risk aversion, consistent with US adult population where majority prefer lower-risk financial and life decisions. Mode around 0.43. Ref...[truncated]

grounding.source: Gallup Economic Confidence Index 2024-2025; Fed Reserve SHED 2023; Harvard Youth Poll Fall 2025
grounding.note: Beta(3.5, 2.5) produces mean ~0.583 with right-leaning distribution, reflecting elevated economic anxiety. Gallup 2025 confidence negative; Harvard Youth Poll shows deep economic insecurity among youn...[truncated]

grounding.source: CDC chronic disease prevalence 2023; NIH disease burden statistics; ACS cancer statistics 2024
grounding.note: CDC: ~60% of US adults have at least one chronic condition; ~40% have two or more. ACS 2024: ~2M new cancer diagnoses/year; Alzheimer's ~6.9M Americans. 'Critical' (terminal/degenerative) ~9% covers c...[truncated]
